addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my singular good Lord, the L. Burghley, Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

Mart
y
be nevew of Ipre]

M
r
Bodeley to my L./.
The [.] of 3 Cornetts of Horse of
Hoesden
by
e Enemij.
Beecke
taken by
e Enemij.
6 Marchants shippes taken by
e Plate.
Desireth to have sent to him a Copie of
e
States
Co
m
and Propositions, when
e same shall be exhibited by
em.
The dislike of
Ortels
proposition for w
th
drawing
e Generalls, & to have mony allowed.
They pretend to be [.] w
th
in
es 4 yeres of 300000
l
They like not of 2 foote for one horse.

page.lettertext:
Belgia Ap
r
2 9. 1589
It may please yo
r
L since
e writing of my last, three
Cornets of horse going out of
Hoesden
to cutte of a Convoy
of
e Ennemie, folowed their prey so farre, as in their
retrait,
e Ennemie, being strong of 400 horse, and
500 footemen, sett uppon them in a streat passage, and
killed a great part, taking almost all
e rest prisoners.
In this exploit
e first onsett was given by
Neus
e
chief mutiner of
Getrudenbergh
. one of
e Cornets belon-
ged to
Count
Maurice
, an other to
Villiers,
and
e third
to
Kintzky
,
being accounted the three best
at we had.
And there are left in these Provinces scarce twice so many
horses besides. Their adventure is generally condemned,
considering
e strength of
e Ennemie in every corner of
those quarters, and
e want of footmen of o
r
part, or as-
surance of any retrait.
Hoesden
is very muche weak-
ned by it, having in it at this p
nt
but
600
men, wheras
1600 are thought w
t
e fewest for defence of
e towne.
Wheruppon it is feared,
at he will thither out of hand:
having lately brought to
Langhestrate
great stoare of
artillerie. Moreover
e dikes about
Hemerts
weert
, are so dried up in divers places, as they are thought
to be passable: whereby
at place will falle to
e Ennemie,
and
Bommel
in great daunger
, for that
e people of
at Ilande are more then half discontented already.
Also
e Ennemie hath taken of late
e
Beecke,
and
put all w
t
in the fort to
e sworde, some 14 persons ex-
cepted. It is thought theruppon
at
Berch
and
Blien-
blecke
, are unable to w
t
stand any force. Certain
boates of
Rossendale
and
Steenberghen
have taken, of
this contrey, six marchantes shippes, by
e
Plate,
whiche
is in
e passage between
Holland
and
Zeland.
The
Duke
causeth, bothe in those two places, and at Ger-
trudenbergh a great number of bigge boates to be
made, w
t
whiche it is feared he will so fill all
at
passage, as hardly any shippe shall passe w
t
out a char-
geable Convoy: w
ch
doutles will putte this people in a
great discontentm
t
, for want of their usuall traffique.
Heere is order taken for renforcing of all their garrisons,
and for
e levieng of
15 companies more
, but
ei knowe
not where to finde souldiers, al men being weary of their
harde intertenment: in so muche as certaine
at were
raised of late at
Dordrecht
,
refused openly to take othe to
e states, but only to Count
Maurice,
and
e towne of Dordrecht.
fol.178v
The states are busied at this present, in setting downe
Instructions for their
Deputies
, w
ch
they send to her
Ma
tie
.
Howbeit they doe keepe them so secret to themselves, as I
can not by any meanes learne w
at
they are. But in pri-
vat conference, whiche I have had of late w
t
Mons
r
Valcke
,
I might perceave
at
e autoritie of her Ma
ties
generall,
wilbe a speciall point of their charge: and it shold semme
by his speeches,
at they will resolve to yelde
to [.]
as muche autoritie unto him, as her Hig
nes
will demande.
Wheruppon I told him,
at it was demaunded already,
in
at declaration whiche I presented to
e Generall states,
uppon their newe Instructions to
e Councell of state:
whiche did manifestly notifie
e generals autoritie.
Against those
Instructions of
e states,
there hath no man
heere at any
man
time bin more earnest, then M
r
Valcke
himself. And though both
he
and
Loozen
,
and many others
are of themselves very indifferent, and dislike altogether
of
e course
at is taken in many thinges heere, yet they
will not dare to passe
at Commission,
at they shall re-
ceave, whiche for ought I can perceave is not like to
be so ample, as is requisit. If yo
r
L. uppon
e presen-
tac
o
n of it, and of all their propositions, shalle thinke
good to send hither a copie of them, I will returne a
present answear: and somwhat perhaps wilbe signi-
fied, wherof yo
r
L. may desire to be informed. I
might conjecture by Valcke,
at
they
are rather desirous to
have a Generall heere for her Ma
tie
then otherwise: be-
cause they are persuaded, they shall never otherwise be
able to keepe her Ma
ties
people in any good discipline:
as I see many tokens for mine owne part, to thinke them
in a right opinion.
Ortels motion for an allowance
to be made in mony, in lieu of her Ma
ties
forces, seemed
by his talke to be disliked of heere: for
at they never
willed him from hens to proceede to that offer, nether
do I judge
at they will harcken unto it, esteeming
e
very name and countenance of her Ma
ties
protection
as great a benefit as
e assistance it self. It appeared
also by him,
at they will send
two marchants to ac-
compagny their deputies, and to deale in
e mater of
traffique: wherein he affirmed,
at they can make ac-
count of more then
three hundred thousand poundes
sterling
at they are
e worse by
England
w
t
in these fower
yeres. I doe not thinke, I told him,
at they can make
that reckning good: but I thought it would be easie for her
fol.179v
Ma
tie
to make evident demonstrac
o
n,
at
e furnishing of
the Ennemie, out of these contreis, w
t
munition and other
necessaries, hath bin an occasion to her Hig
nes
of spending
twice as muche as
at summe, and
e principall occasion
of
e prolongation of these warres. Moreover wheras
e Treaty doth binde her Ma
tie
to a 1000 horse, it should
not seeme by his speeches,
at they will accept of 2 footmen
for one horseman, albeit I doe thinke, they will make some
other offer: as to have a certaine number of horse, to be
sent from her Ma
tie
and allowance for
e rest in mony.
Of
e time of
e Deputies departure, heere is no certaintie
4 Maij
knowen, but I doe conjecture it will be
six daies
hens.
S
r
Martin Schincke
is come hither
, and desireth contentac
o
n
for his former services, and likewise licence to depart for
Fraunce, or some other place, where souldiers are better
accounted of, finding nothing heere, as he hath told them
openly, but dissention among themselves, and hard usage
towardes those
at doe them service. I can not understand
whether he meane good earnest, or otherwise, but I doe rather
thinke,
at knowing their want is great both of souldiers
and leaders, and
e ennemie ready in many places to
come uppon them, he doth but take
e advantage of this
present opportunitie, to make a better end for himself in
all his causes, as likewise to compasse
e office of Mare-
shall villers, wherof he seemeth desirous, and there is good
likelihood
at he shall obtene it, although
e
Count of Solmes
be his Competito
r
.
Mons
r
Caron
is at
Utrecht,
soliciting
e release of
Deventer.
Having nothing
els at this p
nt
, I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
A
p
29 / 89. Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
